Just so you know!  The Valley Tavern does not have a kitchen so, unfortunately, ordering food from them is not an option.  They do have a carry out option where food from another restaurant can be delivered to you but I'd just eat at one of the adorable locales in Noe Valley and venture on over to the Tavern afterward.

I absolutely cannot emphasize how much I love this place and hopefully I'll have an opportunity to run into some of you there!!
author: Kat R.

description:
Great place to watch games, good service and a large selection of beers on tap. There is also multiple HD screens so you won't miss a thing. Great crowds, especially during big SF games. The best part, FREE food during NFL Sundays!

This is the go to Sports bar!
author: Nate V.

description:
Nice local bar. Fun crowd, mostly local. Great staff. Cool backyard most people are unaware of. Karaoke on Thur.s. Free BBQ on football Sundays.
Cons:  Overpriced pool tables ($2 a game). Overpriced jukebox.
Pros: Awesome staff, strong drinks, nice locals.
author: Jojo S.

description:
Is this your average tavern? I think not. 

We walked past the bar since my friends told me that back up past the pool tables, there was a large wooden patio (though it closes at sunset). As we walked to the back, we came across "Free Food" and "Free Hamburgers, Sausages & Steak" signs. Turns out the Valley Tavern was having their anniversary, though we did find out that on some Sunday Afternoons they serve free food, anyway.

Cheap beer, large establishment.
author: Anna R.

description: awesome cocktails (giggity)... great place to chill very friendly even when they are busy. Quality booze attention to detail in making cocktails and solid knowledge of recipes. FRIENDLIEST staff Ive ever met at a bar.
author: Neil V.

description: The tavern is my favorite neighborhood dive. It's always a great place to grab a beer and catch up with the homies, its never too crowded or filled with weird creepers. They have a bunch of beers on tap, I think 15-20 different beers, and they also have great cocktails, some which include house infused vodka. I especially recommend the  bloody mary's which I like to get with a blend of horseradish and chipotle house infused vodkas. One of the great things about the tavern is the back patio which is a great place to get together on a sunny day!!! All the bartenders are super friendly! I also especially appreciate being able to order food from Noe's and they'll come bring it over to you at the valley tavern!
author: Sophie C.

description: Oh, Valley Tavern... my love affair with you started on a cold Pink Saturday night in the summer of 2010 when my group made a hasty exit from the Castro in a hail of gunfire. Even though I live on the other side of the hill from Noe in Cole Valley, the Tav (as my friends and I affectionately call it) would eventually become one of my favorite places to hang out in San Francisco. A good night usually begins with a visit to the Tav to check in with Declan, Kelly Jo, Marie, Olivia and the rest of the awesome staff that have become so much more than that--we're even friends on Facebook, y'all. We've come to call this place "the living room," because that's really what it is. Just so happens my living room has a huge selection of beers on draught, awesome bartenders, and was the place where I watched my Giants in every game of the 2010 World Series.
author: Rich U.

description: I love this place soooo much!! The amount of beers they have on tap is crazy!!:) went in to watch the game when it was slammed and I got served so quickly by the nicest bartenders!! And they have servers up and down the floor all the time checking on you. This is one of the best bars Iv been too. Il be back for sure. :)
author: Linda M.

description:
Can I give this place 6 stars?

Our waitress, Liz/Kat/Melissa/Fergie/etc., was the coolest person EVER.  She was super attentive, really fun and even bought us a round of drinks.  I love her.  Come to Valley Tavern!
author: Evan L.

description:
As far as Noe Valley bars go, this one's the best. They have a solid selection of beer, and I particularly like that they have two pool tables. The tables are a little tight on the wall side, but the fact that we can generally find one free on a Saturday night makes me happy. 

So, you'll find me here when I'm too lazy the roll down the hill to one of the Mission bars.
author: Kristen B.

description:
A group of us came here after prepartying at a friends place near Dolores Park following the Naked Earth wine event at Atlas Cafe.

After enjoying a couple bottles of Hennessey and some Mothership Wit brewskis, we decided to hit up Valley Tavern. My co worker used to live in Noe and said it was the best bar on 24th St.  Immediately upon exiting the bldg to walk down there, the J came, saving us an eight block walk. Nice!

I liked this place. It's a good spot to go with a group of friends. The bartenders, all cute girls, were fun and friendly. Some rounds of drinks were stiffer then others, but cheap! Cheap, as in 2 ketel ones and a stella for 17.50. 

The elevated area with pool tables is an added bonus. They even have a smoking room.. I don't think I've seen that in SF before! Besides Harlot.. I'll definitely go back if I happen to be in the Noe/Mission-Dolores area again.
author: Joel L.

description: Fabulous place. Super clean and lots of TVs. Wonderful staff and customers. Enjoyed Irish coffees made the way they're supposed to be made.
author: Curt E.

description:
NUMBER 400, Bitches!!! 

Valley Tavern is, as of this past Saturday, October 27, 2007, on my list of favorite places. Not only did they graciously allow us to take over their bar and patio for an SF Food Bank Fund Raiser and Live Date Auction, but it is also the establishment where Matthew Capital R officially bought the cow (me, mooooo) when he already gets the milk for free. That's right. Matthew outbid everyone for a date with moi, who he already gets to do a lot more than date with. Aaah, My Hero!

I used to avoid Valley Tavern. Mostly because I'd spent more than a few nights there, being hit on by men old enough to be my dad. But Valley Tavern appears to have changed a lot in the past 4 years. The crowd is younger, the bar staff is quick and generous, and the owners are clearly saints of the highest caliber. (In addition to allowing a full Yelp takeover for fund raiser purposes, they also gave us beer specials and donated a percentage of sales for Saturday night). 

There were hot boys aplenty, drink orders were filled quickly, and  the place is huge as far as neighborhood bars go. There are pool tables and lots of tvs to watch sports on, too.  On principle alone, I'll be back and I'll recommend Valley Tavern for parties, get-togethers, and afternoon drinking on the patio. 

Thank you Valley Tavern for a memorable night. I look forward to more.  Thank you, Euge and JR, for bringing everyone together for such a great cause. And thank you, boyfriend, for making me the happiest girl in the whole universe :)
author: Autumn K.

description:
My dear friend Rachel and I stopped in here last night for a couple of beers before her date at the Mayan restaurant down the block.  She had Pilsner Urquell, I had Czechvar (I know, I know - not really in keeping with my "think globally, drink locally" credo; I made up for it be drinking extra Trumers later on in the evening).  We had just discussed exactly how late she should be (7 minutes, that was my opinion) when whom did she spot ordering a martini at the bar, but her date!  Literally one minute before their scheduled meeting time.  Oh, snap!

Anyhow - hilarity ensued.  I entertained them with my Mitch Hedberg impressions, endeavored to make him feel comfortable that I wasn't stealing his date, while at the same time not so comfortable that he wouldn't feel like he needed to work for it.  He bought me another beer, we all had some laughs, and the two love birds flew off to dinner.  All's well that ends well.

Oh yeah - nice bar.
author: Joe C.

description:
I had a friend that used to live down the street from Valley Tavern above the Supercuts. During midweek when she felt like it, she'd just leave the house in her pajamas and roll into one of the nearby bars. That was years and years ago and I'd not been to this part of town since, so when I drove here today, the deja vu started kicking in. 

Upon entry you notice that the place is sectioned into many little pockets of hangouts, all with ample access to one of many tv's to view sports. There's a small cove on the right side of the doorway, the main room with the long bar to the left and booths to the right, a step up the pool tables and then outside where there are three more levels of outside patio. Today, Yelpers basically took over the outside area where Yelper Euge L. hosted an SF Foodbank Fundraiser. I had promised to man the BBQ station so I went to the very top of the patio to find a Weber coal kettle and another large gas grill waiting for me. As I started firing the two up people start drifting in and even the manager comes out to greet us. I assure her that I will try not to set the back of her bar on fire and that we'll behave for the sake of the residential neighbors behind the bar. Pretty soon  ribs, leg of lamb, trip tip, whole bbq chicken and booze is flowing and every one is having a good time. Other treats where homemade salsa/guac, pasta salad, rice crispy treats, Pastry Chef Yelper Laine L's amazing cupcakes and tons of other goodies. To top it off there's a fried chicken cookoff going down with Yelper JR H. from Selecta Auto next door allowing the participants to fry up in his shop and that food makes its way over to the Tavern too. It was funny to be running back and forth between the two place carrying tongs, knives and trays with people in the streets giving me funny/dirty looks. As the night progressed we gathered everyone inside to the pool area and various Yelpers were auctioned for the fundraiser. Amongst the World Series, Cal-ASU sports watchers, and costumed Halloween celebrators, we became one large rowdy crowd. 

I have to give kudos to the staff at Valley Tavern because, not only were they super cool about letting go us rampant on the place, they were some of the friendliest servers ever, and more than willing to help promote the fundraiser. Hell they even let me cook with large amounts of fire and explosive propane :)

Guinness on tap (a personal favorite) as well as many other cheap tasty drinks, great staff, pretty cool patrons and laid back vibe. What more could you ask of a neighborhood bar?
author: Kim N.

description:
Great service!
Friendly staff!
Fat Tire on tap!
Outside patio area!
Selecta Auto Body next door! 
Rock star parking!

What else would you need in a bar?
author: Kevo M.

description:
I'll always have great memories of the Valley Tavern. Though I'll admit, this was my first legal bar & beer way back when..so I may be a bit biased. However, it has a certain comfy Noe Valley vibe to it that most friends tend to appreciate. After a long night of hopping through the Mission or Castro, I definitely sigh with relief once I've almost made it home and can enjoy the last call somewhere the crowd isn't pretentious and the bartenders are sweet & welcoming.

Ok, so the pool tables are a little cramped, but overall the layout of the place is great for a small neighborhood pub. The ladies bathroom is clean and rarely full of wasted girls doing who knows what. The crowd varies depending on the night, but generally Noe Valley locals tend to take the majority. *Just an FYI to those who think Noe Valley is made up entirely of "yuppy" moms, dads and their golden retrievers; try to look past the borders of 24th street on a weekend afternoon and you might see another picture. 

Valley Tavern: Awesome selection of beers on tap and consistently tasty cocktails for the price. Love the jukebox! Great place for good company and always a fun night in the neighborhood.
author: Coco P.

description:
The Valley Tavern is my chosen temple at which I worship all that is holy in Texas football on Sundays - the Dallas Cowboys.

(but don't fear... it's not a Cowboys bar, it's usually just me and one other fan ;-) it's a pretty balanced crowd.)

The Bay Area is a television nightmare for football fans, because we are treated each and every week to two local broadcasts of the NFL's bottom feeders.   If I lived in LA or Portland for instance, I'd get the best feature games on TV every week, but not here.  Despite this, i'd rather live here so don't hate.  I'm too cheap and do not want 200+ channels of TV to get "The Dish."  So, I've come to accept watching games at the bar, and hey - it feels kinda "European" watching games with groups of strangers.

I've visited many many bars over the last 10 years to watch football, and this is my fave.  You don't feel too crowded, there's natural light, (sunlight, not the beer) high ceilings, there are patios in the front AND back!  then you've got the other good stuff... pool table, pinball, jukebox, etc.

but wait it's gets better!

KAT:
BEST
BARTENDER
EVAH!!!

When you become a regular, Kat remembers what you drink.  I don't even need to say anything, she can read me when I walk in like Dan Haren taking signs - fastball (Stoli bloody mary), splitter (Guinness), or curveball (Mexican coffee.)  She makes the most amazing bloody mary mix by hand too which makes it a great hangover cure. 

This year, they've also added a buffet of food every Sunday that you can pay whatever you want for a plate of food!  What a bar!
author: christoph s.

description: I think this has officially become my favorite neighborhood bar. Great beer selection and lots of drink specials, friendly bartenders, lots of TVs if you're in a sports viewing mood (but placed in such a way as to be non-obnoxious if you're not), pretty good drink specials, lively but not overly crowded. Basically everything I need in a drinking establishment.
author: Pat M.

description:
Noe Valley is a daytime neighborhood for me, so I am not in the bars there all that often.  I had been to the Valley Tavern a while ago, and thought it was a pretty decent place.

Today, at the Cupcake Bake-Off, I discovered the back patio.  There are 3 levels of chill space, hidden like a secret just behind the pool table area.  Sweet!  Outdoor drinking spaces are the BEST, and uncrowded ones are rare.  And because it is smack dab in the middle of a residential neighborhood, patrons are asked to keep their noise level to a minimum, which is cool with me.  I just want to bask in the sun and enjoy my drink.

We had a great event today, and it was nice of the Valley Tavern to accommodate our large group.  Hidden gems like this are what make our neighborhoods great.
author: Liz S.

description:
Ah, date #2. Always interesting, never know where it's going to lead. Date #1 was surprisingly good, very spontaneous, full of laughs, so I had high expectations for Date #2. 

We planned to meet at Mi Lindo Yucatan at 7:00 for some Mayan food and sangria. Since it's right next door to the Valley Tavern, and I kind of miss Noe Valley at times, Joe C. and I (not my date, mind you) decided to have some pre-date drinks at VT. 

The beers went down well, there was ample sports and such to watch on the myriad of TV's there, and the crowd was rather jovial for 6:00 on a Monday. So jovial it seems that someone had to be poured into a cab before 7:00. How does that happen so early on a Monday? 

Anyway, apparently Date #2 and I had the same idea, because he rolled into the VT a few minutes before 7:00 to have a pre-date cocktail. I'm sitting there in my date get-up, chatting it up with Joe at the bar...well, this isn't awkward at all! 

Date #2 looked a bit surprised to find me there, but I was quick to put him at ease, letting him know that Joe was my buddy and that he was going to skedaddle as soon as it was dinner time. Well, no problem, Date #2 bellied up to our conversation and made himself right at home. 

The Valley Tavern has a nice patio, a smoking room right on the street, and plenty of room. And the bathrooms are non-offensive. 

All in all, a great place for somewhat awkward pre-date drinks with a friend and your date.
author: Rachel F.

description:
I've been to the Valley Tavern twice.

Once to sit and drink beer and plan an event and once to attend the event.

They have Boddington's on tap. That's right, you too can drink a properly poured cream of Manchester at the Valley Tavern.

There is food sold from next door (a magical place) which is very good. I had a bacon cheeseburger with fries both times I was there and it was excellent both times.

The owner is nice enough to offer his bar on a weekend day to us for a fundraiser at no charge.

The outside patio is wonderful. Constructed with three tiers the first two are protected from the elements and the third one is open to the sun and wind and rain.

For those smokers around there are two options. The outside patio which is very nice that you can smoke AND drink and not have to chose. But there is a second option -- in the front of the bar they have an inside glass smoking room with windows opened to the outside.
author: Shelly V.

description:
I like this place because they didn't judge me when I got sloshed here at 11am.  Now that's professionalism.
Also, they have cheap pool and cheap pinball.  And generally a good layout.
Bartender got me to try a Wyders and Guinness mix.  Surprisingly good, considering I openly call people "pansies" if they order a plain Wyders.  
I'm definitely going back.  Maybe this time at night?

UPDATE: I went back (in the cloak of darkness, i.e. at night) and was pleasantly surprised to discover that Monday night is Trivia night!  Good trivia, and I can confidently say that I would have won by a landslide if I had not gotten sloshed and forgotten to turn in my last entry card.

UPDATE #2:  I went back again, vaguely recalling that I had enjoyed my truncated experience at Trivia Night.  However, as this time I was plagued by a raunchy sinus infection, I kept beverage consumption to a minimum.  Turns out Trivia Night is meant for a much, MUCH older crowd.  I do not have any idea who Bea Arthur's first husband is.  
Oh, the rare clarity of sobriety.
author: Christine M.

description:
Waiting for my piss-drunk boyfriend and friends to meet stone-cold-sober me after they get out of a party in bayshore, I wandered down 24th to find a drink somewhere and try to play a quick game of catch-up.

Passed Bliss Bar, and the 16 or so unattractive, douchbaggy guys outside tried to get in my way so I couldn't pass: really guys?  Really?  In what world does that ever get you the girl?

At any rate, clearly I'm not going in there.

Valley Tavern was a breath of fresh air after inhaling all the cheap cologne and hair gel fumes.  Normal, fun people, good beer, flat screens filling me in on my Sox, and a juke box where two wasted girls are trying to figure out who sang 'Take On Me'.  Clean, spacious bathrooms are also always a plus.

I was particularly entertained when the bartender went to card my friend, who said, "Do you really think I'd wear pigtails to a bar if I were under 21?"  She got her beer.
author: Caitlin M.

description:
i came here a lot to watch sport events with my friends, one of those neighborhood bars where u see the usual, old faces
they have 2 pool tables in the back and some videogames as well
the bartenders are super friendly and ppl are nice here
and there is a little area near the entrance where u can smoke but its still connected to the bar itself

and i love their karaoke fridays here, one time i walked in with my friends and i decided to sing California Love - Tupac feat. Dr. Dre

all these ppl are like looking at me "whats this nerdy asian doing here?"
then i sang the shit HARD, ppl started cheering for me and i got the ppl singing California Love with me, and ppl gave me daps and hugs at the end
its an awesome bar, you should def. check it out

4 tars
author: Michael K.

description:
So we had a cupcake bake off contest here at Valley Tavern...Wait, did I just say what I think I just said? Why yes, I did! We had an awesome cupcake contest at a freaking BAR!!! In most parts, it sorta worked...Up until the bitchy bartender started carding everyone. Really? Do we look like we're under 21? Some of us have beards and wrinkles that would make Joan Rivers flinch! Don't be taking it out on us just because you have a problem with working without any help on a day that soocer was being televised on the tube. Seriously, attitude adjustment, please.

Now, this is just a review for the bar, not the event that we Yelpers had at the bar. Hence the low score. Remember, score the joint, not the event! Unless the event royaly blew but that was not the case this time. Yay CUPCAKES!!!
author: Anthony L.

description:
While this joint is a little far from my neck of the woods, it's definitely a winner.

It's this sort of divey sports bar, with Noe Valley's locals. Lots of nice people, a hot bartender (who gives free shots for no apparent reason), and smoking hot box if that's your thing.

Only drawback was the lighting. I'm a fan of the dimly lit places, and this wasn't one of them.

Not my first pick for a bar, but definitely a cool place to chill with friends & sip some drinks.
author: matt m.

description: not too much to say about this place - good list of beers, no food, serivce Meh.
author: Belinda B.

description: This is my first review on yelp and glad I'm giving it to the valley tavern. The service here is top notch and I can't get over how efficient and friendly the staff at this place is. They can make any drink you can think of and they are happy to serve it with a smile! Thank you valley tavern for making my day.
author: Brian W.

description:
Full service bar with wooden booths against the walls to eat and drink. Front section to drink and smoke (i don't but will do cigars). There's a back a patio (this is where the date part comes in) to hang out. No its not a backyard with chairs there's tables and foliage around. 

There's a pool table to practice your hustling skills. And of course there's tv's to watch sex and the city (yea right) a game is always on. Prices are reasonable and the bartenders are friendly.
author: Lola L.

description: Love love love it here!! Everyone that works here is awesome! The vibe is mellow, the beers on tap are plentiful and there's never a dull moment in the smoking room;0) My home away from home for sure!
author: Veronika O.

description:
I love this place..and maybe I am a bit partial because i work next door, but I love the feel in the bar. I am not a Bliss Bar guy, no offense to the Bliss Bar at all, but that's not me. The Valley Tavern is great for sports, hanging out and drinking related holidays and more. The bartenders are friendly and the people that are in there are cool.
If in Noe Valley, stop in and have a beer!!
author: JR H.

description:
Went with a couple of buddies last night for pub quiz and had an awesome time!  The entire wall behind the bar is covered in tv's, just in case you needed something to entertain you besides the current beverage at hand.  

The Mexican place next door supplies the pub's eats, and even though they MESSED UP THE ORDER, I'm not gonna focus on that.  My chicken quesadilla was decent, and I must say that it's amusing to see cheeseburgers offered at a Mexican place as well.  :)

Pub quiz never starts on time.  Sorry, not getting drunk beforehand.  I need to be fully capable of answering the awesome pub quiz questions.  :)  Anyway, we got 3rd place and got a few free pints.  I've never won anything in pub quiz EVER.  So I now have a soft spot on my impressionable heart for Valley Tavern.
author: Emily C.

description: I think I'm slowly becoming a fan of drinking in Noe Valley. A nice watering hole up from Bliss Bar, with fantastic bartenders to boot. These girls knew their stuff and tossed out great jokes, all while remaining sober. Dive bar/pub like setting, plus the well priced booze, minus the gross bathrooms and spotchy service.
author: Alita M.

description:
Good place to grab a pint and watch a rugby game.  That's right, I said rugby.  

Lots of stools to saddle up at the bar, tables for groups, and a large (multilevel) beer garden in the back.  Lone window seat is a coveted spot.  

Wouldn't make it an all-nighter, but it's a solid starting point.
author: Kate L.

description:
Your neighborhood tavern and mine!
Why? because they had a chicken fried fest food a thon!
author: J A.

description:
This is a great neighborhood bar, with cheerful staff able to manage large crowds and make you feel like you are the #1 customer.  Multiple screens and football games with BBQ that is quite tasty.  Green salad along with standard BBQ fare.
Many cheers for the home team.  
Definitely a fun place to watch sports on an afternoon.  I am a fan.
author: D'oh S.

description:
I'm so pleased Yelp included the Valley Tavern on its latest email newsletter because it reminded that I have yet to review it and give it the smallest score possible.

After being pretty frequent visitors for a number of years, back to when it was the Rat and Raven, we decided that it would be the best place to watch the World Cup Final in July 2006. We showed up early, at 9am, giving us a good while before the game started, and we made sure to start with the drinking there and then. More of our friends arrived and before long there were about 10 of us, all drinking beers except for one designated driver who was drinking coffee.

Midway through the game I went up to the bar to order more drinks and some water for the DD. They proceeded to charge $3 for a glass of tap water. When I questioned it, the owner came over, Mr. Grumpy Money-Grabbing Irishman guy (his real name is Vincent M. Hogan according to the CA ABC website) and got all up my face. He said they couldn't have people in there on the busiest day of their year drinking for free. I explained that she was the DD, that the rest of us were drinking (and had been for a while) and that she wasn't looking for bottled water, just from the tap. I suggested that they should be encouraging DDs like many other bars, especially when they're making damn good money off all the people she's transporting to and from the bar.

Now it got really unpleasant.

Anyone who knows me knows I'm not the aggressive fighting type so it was pretty damn surprising to be physically threatened by this obnoxious little fuckwit. Not wanting to ruin the game for my friends I backed down and told Mr. Asshat he wouldn't see me or my friends in any of the bars he and his wife own again.

FYI, that includes the Dubliners on 24th St and West Portal.
author: Neil S.

description:
great place to go after work and have a few beers.....friendly people, nice staff and very comfortable. Great place to hang out with some friends to talk crap and catch up.  
The tv's are great for sports too.  Bathrooms are a bit smelly but I guess most pub bars are like that?????
author: luke b.

description:
Noe Valley conjures up visions of everything suburban. We all know the stereotypes: babies, dogs, strollers, land rovers. 

Valley Tavern is like a little piece of urban heaven amidst the otherwise quietness of 24th St. The music is always upbeat (although somewhat random due to the jukebox; Genie in a Bottle followed by Don't Stop Believin'?), there's a great mix of people, pool tables, great selection of beers on tap (I counted at least 16), and Liz is the coolest cool chick/bartender/server in the Valley. Not the best date place, but a great place to sip and chat with friends. Also, they're a little snarky about verifying your ability to pay before you start a tab, but whatevs.

BONUS: You can order food from the next-door Mi Lindo Yucatan. Tasty apps and entrees delivered right to your seat at the bar!
author: Matthew S.

description:
I must say that despite the generic feel to this bar and how crazy packed it can get on the weekends, I still think this is my favorite local watering holes (Dubliner loses points for being more than 2 blocks away.  Can we say, "Chris is a lazy bastard?  Ah knew ya could.").  

The bartenders are nice.  The beer selection is pretty good.  The music is (usually) good and customizable through the use of those nifty Internet jukeboxes.  The clientele is good.  Just all around good stuff.
author: Chris M.

description: Solid bar to jump in and grab a drink. Came here with friends and there is ample room to walk around or sit by the bar. There is a solid selection of beers to choose from as well. I wouldn't go out of my way to come here, but if a friend told me to meet them at Valley Tavern I would definitely not complain and go meet them for a beer.
author: Sebastien D.

description:
Another stop on the Pub Quiz circuit.  Random J and I went here last night as a 2-man team and got clobbered.  Damn music round...I swear these new artists all sound the same.  At least I got "She's Not There" by the Zombies.  Also, it's got the same British guy emcee from Martin Mack's, and he's definitely the best of the quizmasters.

As for the bar itself, it's equal parts pub, sports bar, and dive, with a surprisingly non-Noe Valley clientele (one pub quiz team called themselves "The Laptop and Blackberry Crowd" and was roundly booed).  Despite having 18 beers on tap, the selection was pretty "been there, drank that...hey what's that red one?  Oh, just Amstel Light.  Damn."

Between this place and Bliss Bar, you've got your basic bar needs covered in Noe Valley.  Or, if you're really preppy, you can get your sports & pints thing on at the Dubliner instead, but I like Valley Tavern better as it's not quite so sterilized.
author: Wes M.

description:
We were having dinner next door with a friend visiting from New York and decided that it was to early to call it a night just yet.  Having walked past the Valley Tavern on our way in we decided to stop in for a quick drink. 

Much to my surprise, and inevitable glee, we stumbled into the middle of a pub quiz!  For the next hour, we were able to astonish and amaze our out-of-town friend.  She apparently had no idea that I was a veritable fountain of information about old TV sitcoms, or that my boyfriend's arcane political acumen could come in so handy, or that our other friend was absolutely indispensable when it comes to identifying songs based on two seconds heard in a noisy bar.  Apparently, they don't have quizzes in New York. Or, at least she had never heard of one.  Poor people!

Valley seems like a good place to go for quiz, especially if you are new to the idea.  You could actually hear the quizmaster (and he sounded sober, which is rarer than you may think.)  The questions were a nice blend of difficult with some gimmes thrown in to keep your confidence up.  

I'm hesitant to give the quiz a real score though, since we were only there for the last part.  But, we'll be back to try out the quiz in it's entirety and I'll do my best to update the review then...
author: Tiffany S.

description:
The Valley Tavern is just how I like my bars:

Affordable drinks
Good music (80's music!)
Relaxed atmosphere
Clean bathroom
and I can hear what my friends are saying (aka we aren't shouting)

I'm definitely going back.
author: M O.

description:
On the plus side, if you are a smoke there's a little glassed-in nook for you that opens onto the street.

My only beef with the place is that it feels a little too big for what it is: a decent neighborhood bar. If it were on Valencia or Mission St. it would work better. It's a bit lost in mommy/daddy - mommy/mommy land.
author: Karsten P.

description:
I went to happy hour here last night and really had a great time. This place has a great feel to it. I like how my husband put it: "this is how bars should be." It was warm and welcoming, and had a great layout. Lots of seats at the bar, as well as tables and booths along the other wall. The pool tables are a great aspect, but I was disappointed that the patio closed at 730pm as I wanted to sit out on the great deck. (I suspect it closes so early b/c the bar backs up to a residential area.) 

Great beer selection on tap, and a full bar to boot. The service was good as well - early in the evening ("Breakfast," according to my bill) we had to order at the bar, but as the night wore on we had table service. We also ordered some food, which is delivered to you from the place down the street (we never did figure out exactly where it was coming from). It was typical bar food, but did the trick. 

This is the type of place I'd go to regularly if I lived in the area. Hopefully I'll have some excuse to go back in the future.
author: Danielle S.

description: One of my neighborhood bars. We have a few here in Noe. I like this place. And they have pool tables... Oh if only my girlfriends from San Diego were here. We would rock those tables and a few beerz. I like the selection of good beer on tap. Chimay and Guinness are my faves. But then I am Scottish. Part of me is anyway. We are not sure which part. But it loves beer and real Whiskey.  The drinks are descent too. And the redhead.... whoa. Yeah I am a dirt old broad. I'll stop while I am ahead. ;-)
author: Nichole S.

description:
I think that the problem with this bar is the location. It's got pool tables (but there isn't enough space for them-- be prepared to use the special 18'' cue stick they've kindly provided for when the cue ball is anywhere near the wall), a pinball machine, a juke box, some very friendly bartenders (tip Sarah and tip her well) and yet... it's kinda dull.

 I imagine that this place is quite nice on a warm evening, what with the beer-garden out back, and it's great for an afternoon brew, but nearly every time I go there I find myself on the phone with friends making plans to move elsewhere. Perhaps it's the crowd, which consists largely of older men. Or maybe i've just been going at the wrong times.
author: Jonathan A.

description:
As discussed in previous reviews, I am not one for the traditional bar or pub.  My normal style when going out for drinks is more of a laid back lounge scene.  Somewhere that has a cocktail menu along with the traditional extensive selection of beers.  It's just more my style.  Usually I hate frequenting bars or pubs where there are loads of loud sports fanatics cheering during the latest playoff, but The Valley Tavern seems to be the exception to my own rule.

The tavern looks completely divvy on the outside in my opinion, therefore making me believe that the inside would reflect their grungy outward appearance. Not true.  I was shockingly pleased with how clean and nice the inside actually was.  And there was plenty of seating besides at a bar stool!  Although decorated like your average sports bar & pub, it is done nicely which earns it points in my book.  

The drinks are generally cheap and decent, and they have a couple of pool tables and pinball machines, which add a nice addition to the place.  I do on occasion enjoy a good game of pool (even though I suck), so the pool tables definitely helped in my overall first impression.  My good friend and I got our butts kicked a few weeks back...but it was all in good fun (it was HER fault we lost).

So if you're like me, and weary (or sometimes even scared) of entering those sketchy run down hole in the wall bars, give The Valley Tavern a chance.  You might be pleasantly surprised.
author: Ryan H.

description: Solid, not-too-loud bar for locals with a cool outdoor smoking area - even though I am not a smoker. Funny place where an older man in his late 60's or early 70's walked up to my table, completely loaded, and said "excuse me, I am drunk. what should i do?" Also cool was the option of Anchor Bok at reasonable prices. Not too loud, comfy, and just chill. Noe is the cutest.
author: Andrew K.

description:
This is a review for the day of the 2nd Annual Yelp Cupcake Bakeoff.

The chick bartender was nice enough but seemed confused when I ordered a Midori Sour and asked her to go easy on the alcohol. I just didn't want a strong drink on an empty stomach prior to gorging myself on cupcakes.

Really nice patio area that would be lovely on a less crowded occasion.

Several times the bartender had to come out and shush us. I guess we have to be quiet on the patio as to not bother the neighbors. Isn't that kind of weird though? I mean, if you live next to a bar, don't you go in with the understanding that bars get noisy?
author: Christine K.

description: Came here to continue celebrating best friends bday, it was a blast! Bartenders were awesome and joined in on the fun! thank you valley tavern!
author: Tiff W.

description: Visited Valley Tavern on a Wednesday night from about 730p-1130p. The bartenders working were nice and the waitress was definitely attentive. I was a little bummed that although there is a hanging sign outside the door that says beer garden they were out of 3 different beers we wanted. Other than that the place is great. There is a patio out back that I would like to come back and visit some sunny afternoon and a separate smoking room that is visible but not "smellable" from inside the main bar room. The place has some pools tables and a few games in the corner as well as a high tech juke box. You can bring in your own food or order delivery since they do not serve food which I thought was pretty awesome. If you order from Bossa, the waitress will call for you.$5 dollar beers + nice atmosphere + friendly peeps = not a bad place to grab a few beers.
author: Tuesday C.

description:
Update 3-07-07:  On the good side, this place has gained a bit of character by displaying local artwork.  On the downside?  It's gotten extremely young, and worse yet.....very boy-heavy.  I'm just too old for this place.   The place is infested with teeny boppers and faux surfers, and all of the older folks seem to have vanished.   It's still a decent hangout during the day...but the last five times I've been in here, I've wound up looking around and asking myself the same question: "What the hell am I doing here?".   

(Original Review Below)

Most Drinking establishments gather a culture, a scene, a crowd, or a dominant pack of regulars that pretty much sets the scene and forms an unwritten code of conduct, the likes of which govern any place of congregation.  Once things settle in, you can pretty much predict what'll be happening and who'll be around any time you visit.

The Valley Tavern is not such a place.  Despite it's location smack-dab on 24th street in Noe Valley, it has failed to garner an image that will aid in predicting what type of crowd will be hanging out at any given time.  Two owners ago, the same place played host to an extremely diverse crowd of interesting people.  But the place changed hands during the dotcom era, and the new owners subjected the "Rat and Raven" as it was called, to a an extensive remodel.  Out went the old wood, the worn floors, the creaky doors, and the battle scarred bar....and out went the bar's soul.  The place changed hands again about 4 years ago, and the new owner managed to undo allot of the dotcom era wretchedness that stained the place around the turn of the Milena.  Unfortunately, the character that came with decades of hard wear can't be brought back.  To it's credit, some local artwork of the surrounding area has displaced the buy-in-bulk reproduction beer advertisement decor that plauged the walls until recenty.  Sure, it's a nicely fitted place, but very little about it is distinctly San Francisco.  The entire bar could blend into the scene of any Major U.S. metropolitan area if it was yanked up with it's foundation and moved...

It's a bar that many visit, but few call home.  A small collection of middle to late-middle aged regulars tend to collect at the end of the bar farthest from the entrance, yet they make no effort to mix into the more dominant twenty-something couples and singles that begin to fill the place well after nightfall.

On the positive side, the owner's pro-active management style has been one of weeding out problem patrons such as sloppy drunks, combatitive personalities, and drug dealers.  In short, it's one of the best run bars in the neighborhood.  Peace has it's price however, as the establishment lacks any kind of "edge" that many city dwellers seek out.  Dueling pool tables in the back make a great place for multiple groups to mingle, and a detached smoking area that faces 24th street provides a conversation-friendly refuge from the music, which all too often is loud enough to hinder friendly chat.  A covered patio in the back makes for an even quieter oasis from the noise, and  a clear, corrugated plastic roof lets sunshine in and creates an audible pitter-patter on rainy days.  

The Valley Tavern probably gets almost half of my monthly bar tab, mainly because it's walking distance from home.  It's a got a convenient location, a good beer selection,  and it lacks an insular crowd of overbearing regulars to contend with (i.e., like the Dubliner down the street).  All in all, not a bad place....though somewhat lacking in character and local charm.  I'm considered a regular, but if I lived in another part of the city I wouldn't consider this bar a destination worthy of inter-neighborhood travel......
author: Mike W.

description: Very chill spot, great beer selection, comfy seating, a jukebox, and pretty reasonably priced alcohol.  Love that you can order food from Basso's or Patxi's and they will deliver to you at the tavern.  On a heavy drinking night, when we closed out our tab, the bartender gave us four free drink chips to be used on our next visit - awesome!  We would have come back anyway, but this was even more incentive.  Bartenders are friendly and accommodating.  It's wheelchair accessible - my friend had no trouble getting a spot at the lower part of the bar or getting into the bathroom.  I've never played here, but there are pool tables as well.  Overall, a super chill spot to come and have some beers.
author: Jenna C.

description:
The Valley Tavern has been a local favorite since it was the Rat and Raven and the Coyote Club. The Monday night pub quiz has brought more neighborhood regulars and a few imports.

I believe this is the largest bar in Noe Valley with lots of TVs for game day, and two pool tables. But the real plus of this bar is the beer garden out back. During the World Cup they even put TVs out back so you could watch the game while outside.

The staff here does a good job at taking care of the regulars and treating those who are just passing through. If you are in the neighborhood, stop by!
author: Kemp M.

description:
i teeter between two and three stars b/c my experience wasn't a complete one.  why?  i only played pool and didn't drink anything.  0_o  no, your eyes aren't being deceived.  i stopped in around happy hour on a wednesday to get a couple of pool games in before yoga class.  (nobody likes a liquory yogi.)

i immediately liked the mellow vibe of the place.  dim, w/a familiar feel of a buddy's basement (minus the lack of windows and stale smell).  it seemed like a comfortable spot to be low-key and have a beer.  

so where do the two stars come in?  ...holy miniature pool tables!  ...and $1.25 a game too!  there were two small pool tables in the elevated area in the back.  it was probably the most cramped setup i've ever seen.  not comfortable at all.  i would've gone w/only one pool table.  ...if you want to play pool in this area, i'd go over to the peaks.

i suppose i could go down to one star if i was rating valley tavern solely for its pool tables, but that'd be as ridiculous as rating any establishment based on their bathrooms.
author: Ting A.

description:
If I lived in Noe Valley, this would be my hangout.  

It's the ideal neighborhood bar.  Clean, tavern-y feel, pool tables, clean bathrooms, jukebox, smoking room (not that I smoke, but for the BF that is cool), lots of beer on draft as well as stuff for mixed drinks.  

Not too crowded.  I would say about 80% full which I find rare in SF on a weeknight without any specials (ie. Taco Tuesday, or Trivia Night) going on.  That was good though because then you have a good vibe, but not every seat is taken and it's not nuts to butts in there.  

Service was good, the bartender was super friendly and even bought the BF a shot for his birthday. Not much else to say, I liked it alot and would come back again even if it's not by where I live.
author: Denise B.

description: Came here on a sunny weekend and enjoyed a couple of pints on the super chill back patio. I really liked being able to sit in the dappled sunlight outside (inside, the bar is very dark)  and the no-gimmick, no-nonsense vibe.
author: M M.

description:
Average Bar, pretty typical of the local pub gone corporate (not TGIF corporate, but not much soul in any case.

One wonderful redeeming feature is the bar menu is from the Latin restaurant next door, Mi Lindo Yucatan.  Yum, great food, but the ordering and service is a little wonky.

Good beer selection, but do not try to order a real drink (the kind with clear liquor and no bubbles).

Grab a beer while you are waiting for a table next door, but don't expect much.
author: David R.

description:
I used to love this bar a few years ago...and still very much enjoy the mellow atmosphere/vibe - I was just really disapointed last time I visited.

I was there with a large group who spent plenty of money there and had nothing but respect for the space. I found it rather upsetting when I told the waitress I was sober driver and she charged me $2 for a coke. Even at the most yuppy bars I've never been charged as sober driver, no less TWO DOLLARS for 8 oz. of soda. 

I probably won't recommend to go there again.
author: Erika P.

description: Valley Tavern's beer towers are so great, especially when you have a large group with you. Even more so, when you are with a large group and playing drinking games at the bar... $28 for 3-4 rounds of domestic beer is pretty good. VT is chill and the service is wonderful. They don't have their own kitchen, but you can order of the menu from Basso's and they bring it right to you. I recommend their patio on a nice day... it's pretty cool and fun and all that jazz.
author: Nichole P.

description: They have a great beer selection, pool tables, CLEAN restrooms (yes I did say clean restrooms...in a pub they do exist), and a comfortable environment. The prices are very reasonable and the bartenders are nice and chatting. But one of the main reasons I like this pub is that it is close to home, I could say its stumbling distance but I live in Twin Peaks district so its all up hill so if I do stumble I would be going back in the direction of Noe Valley. None the less the location rocks.
author: Violeta E.

description:
Effin sweet.

Overheard yesterday, I learned that humans fart an average of 14x/day.

Great visible TVs for your weekend sports as well as baseball games.  The beer/booze selection is top notch.  Chimay on tap is the way to my heart.  The prices are just right and they take cards as well.

The staff is friendly and fun as well as the other patrons.

The patio is ridiculously nice.  It is a great place to enjoy an afternoon with a pint and some conversation.  Although, I am confused on whether you can take alcohol all the way in the back of it...if not I'm perplexed on why.

Anywhoo, inside is mad clean and spacious as are the bathrooms.

If I lived nearby this might be one of my first choices for the comfy pub day.  But since I live a 10 min 24 ride away it will be a Noe Valley break and an occasional meeting place for those idiots that live beyond Glen Park and want to meet in the middle.

Oh, yeah...I'm way above average.
author: Chris D.

description: I've come here a few times to watch 49ers or other sports.  Decent, affordable beers.  Pool table in the back.  If you're hungry, they let you order food from a restaurant nearby (pizza/wings/etc).
author: T Y.

description: Love the little BBQ they put on during big games.  Great place to be to watch sports and grab some food/drinks.
author: Jenny C.

description:
**Great for Sunday Football**

My boyfriend dragged me to this bar when we first started dating and I was a little annoyed (especially when he told me that the bartender had a crush on him). However, once I got the dirty martini the way  I like it (filthy dirty) and quarters for the ping ball machine, with a smile- I was very pleased. 

Kat is the best, and if you care, doesn't have a crush on my boyfriend.
author: Paige B.

description: I've celebrated birthdays, graduations, and regular happy hours at Valley Tavern. Never does it disappoint me. Tonight, I visited with an old token for a free drink, and ended up with another two shots on the house for me and my wife. And the bartenders are probably the nicest I've ever met. Not only that, but they KNOW their drinks. Plus, they have some great food from Basso down the street now. See you soon, Valley.
author: Kevin D.

description:
My favorite of the 24th Street haunts... Strong drinks, fun bartenders, lots of beers on tap and pinball.  Add that with a couple of pool tables and a ton of TVs with all the sports you could ask for (including Guy's favorite, FUEL TV on the plasma with XTREME sports!), this place fulfills it's role as a great local bar.

Rotating art installations keep it fresh and they encourage you to have any food delivered to the bar.  The smoking lounge in front (for you lucky bastards who still smoke) and the garden seats in back make it a nice place to relax and chill.

It gets crowded on the weekends, but not intolerably so.  For a drink after work, during the week it can't be beat.  I also seem to find myself there quite a bit during the day on Saturday's and Sunday's, it's a great place to catch a game and practice on my mad pinball skillz.  

I got pretty wasted at the old Tavern a week ago, but that was my fault as I told Katherine it was my birthday and she proceeded to pour Patron and Jaeger bombs into my face.  Bless that girl.  

Not pretentious, always fun.  They could use a better happy hour, but who am I to tell them how to run a business.

**Update:  3.75 Sierra Nevada Happy Hour = SWEET!**
author: Tony A.

description:
Monday Night trivia! Woo.
Nice bartenders, speedy service. A lot of choices to be made.
Local, which is nice.
A generally good, clean place to be. Oh, and a place that opens at 11 on a Sunday is totally fine by me!
author: Meghan B.

description:
We came across  this bar while we were cruising Noe Valley. We just popped in for a beer, and our friend was coming to meet us. We happened upon Monday Trivia Night. We ended up with a team of four and stayed the whole time!

The trivia was pretty fun, adn we did pretty well. The bar filled up quickly, and people were having fun. We ended up getting pretty into it, but we blew our lead in the last round! :( plus there were some crews there who obviously come all the time...

Good beers on tap, two pool tables, pinball machines, and you can order food from M Lindo Yucatan next door. And the Tamale Lady came in!

We will definitely come back to make another go of it! Best part is you get to make up a team name and the nice announcer guy with the accent reads it out load! GO TEAM SWAMP CROTCH!
author: Audrey K.

description:
My friend just recently had a birthday get together here.  This place had a great selection on the jukebox, the drinks were very cheap (I was surprised), and the bartenders were friendly.  Also, they have TVs visible at many angles so you can watch sports (the Olympics was on).  I didn't make it over to the pool tables, but they have them too if that's your thing, plus a little outdoor patio for people to smoke.

Minus 1 star for having to get carded at the bar every time I got a drink.  I would suggest they get a door guy checking IDs at least for the weekends.

Overall, good bar, parking isn't bad and the drinks were priced really well.  I can dig it.
author: Ruben P.

description:
I came here a few nights a go with a good friend of mine to do some catching up.  We were in search of a nice place where we can catch up over a beer or two.

For a Thursday night, there was quite a few people seated at the booths and such.  We picked a location at the end of the bar, away from other patrons.  The music can be a bit loud at times but conversation is manageable.  At least for two people - any more people and we would have been yelling across the table.  At least there weren't strobe lights or anything that would turn this bar into a wannabe dance hall (see voda vodka lounge).

This seems like a good local joint to go to.  Four stars for "I'll come back if I'm in the area and need a place for a beer."
author: Robert L.

description:
Thank you to the Valley Tavern for hosting the Yelp 2nd Annual Cupcake Bake-off.  We had the run of the 3-tiered back patio.  I ordered a couple of Wyder's over the course of the afternoon and the bartender was friendly and the service prompt.  

Over the years, I've been there periodically but the back patio was a (happy) surprise for me.  Valley Tavern is a neighborhood bar that's been around more than a while, in a continually changing neighborhood -- and where the change is (generally) to add more shiny, pretty, spendy places.  Yay for the Valley Tavern!!
author: Nancy W.

description: On a Saturday evening, this place was crowded but we were able to get a drink pretty quickly.  They have a large draft selection which was a plus, and the bartender (who looked 16) was great!  I need to come back to this place on a nice day to hang out on the back patio.
author: Dana D.

description: Every single time I've been to Valley Tavern they greet me with a warm friendly smile. It's little things like that that keep me coming back here.
author: Mark D.

description:
Cool, mellow crowd.  I went on a Thursday night and it wasn't outrageously packed.  Sports on the TVs, people playing pool in the back, and my friend and I enjoying our beers and some nachos.

The nice thing is that their food is from the Mexican place next door.  You can order it at the bar and the restaurant staff brings it over to you.  Just know that you have to pay cash for the food -- you can't add it to your tab.  Pretty wide variety of beers, including the illustrious, always-classy PBR, although I had a Newcastle.

All in all, great neighborhood bar.  Go on, catch up with your friends over a beer.
author: Tamara M.

description:
If you just want to go and drink with your buddies and aren't really interested in being seen, you should consider going to the Valley Tavern.    This is a place to drink more than it's a pick up joint. 

Since it's walking distance from my place I go here and Bliss Bar a fair amount.
author: Josh B.

description: Free food, forgetful bartenders and football games are what I think of when I think of the NVT. After noon they bring out some kind of free food, which varies from week to week. The bartenders there seem to be more interested in conversations going on at the bar than keeping track of everyone's tabs... I've gotten at least one free drink every afternoon spent there(but I tip very well)!
author: Nate S.

description: Weird. It's cozy, they have Chimay on tap (woohoo!), and... a cool bartender girl with buzz cut. I felt very comfortable here, on a solo night out.
author: Maximillian M.

description: This bar is kick ass.  Its like a hidden gem, its got a sweet outside area and inside it's pretty nice too.  Ive never been to noe valley, honestly didnt even feel like i was in sf, but i did like this bar a lot.  Came here on a sunday, so not sure how it usually is, but it wasnt too busy so that was nice and i really liked the outside area.  There was this huge freakin cat thou that looked like a black panther that was like on the fence outside, i hate cats so it was good it just stayed up there.
author: christopher h.

description:
I was visiting San Francisco over NYE weekend. After searching the city for a friendly bar Im so happy I found Valley Tavern. Kelly Jo was my bartender and she was WONDERFUL!!!! She made our night kick ass. She was sweet and quick to make our devil juice. She also ordered  us pizza from next door and had it delivered to the bar! 

Over all Valley Tavern Rocks! Thanks Kelly Jo we will surely be back next time we are up north!!!
author: Magnolia M.

description: Very good bar....one thing I love about this place is they let you bring in your own food since they don't have a kitchen. Fun crowd and trivia nights on Tuesdays are always fun. They have a fair number of beers on tap....best bar in Noe, in my opinion, and I recommend ordering some Patxi's pizza from next door to have with your beer.
author: Drew K.

description: A good place to go have a drink or two on a Sunday afternoon.  Not a place I would want to cozy into myself for the long haul.  For a bar with a lot of TV's was pretty disappointed that the only TV showing my hometown Portland Trailblazers (woot) was changed off in favor of a third TV of the same lacrosse match.  Better luck next time!  Service was good but nothing to write home about.
author: Todd L.

description: I really don't know how you could not like this bar.  It has ample room for being a local hangout, a separate but still enclosed smoking area with it's own tv and heater, plenty of flat screen TVs, pool tables , three outdoor levels (two of which are covered and have TVs and heaters), lots of good beers on tap, and a locking door for the crapper (just bring your poo drops so you don't wreck it for the person coming in after you).  You can even order food from Mi Lindo Yucatan next door from the bar and they bring it to you in the bar.  More bars should be this convenient.
author: Luis M.

description: They have a pretty back patio.  That's kind of nice, right?  And they have that nudie photo hunt touchscreen TV game, I like that.  Pool tables?  Sure!  That's cool. EXCEPT MILLER LITE FOR $4 ISN'T A HAPPY HOUR SPECIAL WORTH BRAGGING ABOUT.   I mean, really?  You can't sell PBR for $2 or $3 like everyone else? I'm sorry, am I at the airport?
author: Laura F.

description:
so after having a couple ordering too many buckets o corona y modelos at playa azul with a client over some delicioso seafood, we decide to hit up some random bars near his place so he could drop off his car. we found ourselves at the valley tavern. what a nice surprise. didnt yelp it, didnt call around, just randomly picked a place and it turned out to be very nice. clean inside, i mean clean. i dont think ive ever seen a bar during opening hours so clean. thats always a plus. two pool tables in back, the usual mp3 jukebox off to the side......

ooooo chimay on tap. nice.

a smoking area? ehhh its right by the door so same thing. 

would definately come back here if i was in the neighborhood. shit drop off your car at selecta autobody next door and come on over for a drink. sounds like a plan.
author: Euge L.

description: This place is great any time of the day or night. They have a wide variety of beers, pool tables, photo booth, a 3-tiered back yard patio, and a smoking room. All that and their bartender, Hank is a great guy. During the day when it quiter, it a great alternative to a cafe if you want a change in scene and a quiet place to work. The fact that they have free WiFi only adds tot he appeal.
author: Vivek N.

description: a mellow local neighborhood bar....nothing fancy or impressive...just comfort the offering...pool tables...various seating options.....friendly cute barmaids.....happy hour specials of $three before seven.....beers on tap averaging $four to $six.....typical local scene....but added benefits of screens, screens and more screens.....sports, games, tv 'n' more...but...do think the delivery food suck pretty bad...bar good....delivery food from near by restaurant bad....
author: Hen A.

description: A top-notch place. It has everything you could want from a bar in quiet little Noe Valley. Two pool tables and an Addams Family pinball machine provide excellent entertainment. Does it get any better? You bet! Trivia night every Monday.
author: Matt M.

description: Good spot to walk to/from the Dubliner for a slight (and I mean slight) change of pace.  Same smoker's lounge, same set-up, similar feel overall.  That's a good thing - both places are solid bars and good to have within a short walk.
author: Brian D.

description: My favorite local pub.  I usually celebrate my bday here, there's always room for a group, they let you bring food in, and it's not hard to get a chance at the pool table.  The only negative is that some nights it turns into a collegiate frat scene around the pool table section in the back.
author: Courtney Y.

description: Pretty darn fun place to go for football games. The free food is kick-ass.
author: Jonny A.

description: Simply the best.  Valley Tavern is acceptable for every night or day of the week.  From Football Sundays with the free BBQ to New Year's day (warding off the hang over) with free cheese and crackers (wait... both of those were day time drinking...), Valley Tavern rocks my world.  They have fun games too, pinball machine, sacks game (corn hole... .what?!!!), pool and I'm pretty sure erotic picture hunt in the back.  They also have a nice back porch thing going on.  Truly a neighborhood hang out.  Thank god it's in my neighborhood (and happens to be the closest bar to my house).
author: Brittney B.

description: I really much enjoyed this place when it was a dark & gloomy dive 10 years ago. Fast forward to the present and the crowd leaves a bit to be desired, but if my favorite drunks are there it's a ton of fun. Plus there is a lot of space, so you can hole up in a corner and forget about the rest of the place. The bartenders seem cool, but I don't know how they work in a place with that much bright light! Ugh.
author: Colleen B.

description: I miss the old days of The Rat & Raven when I lived in Noe Valley.....  It had a great old jukebox full of punk classics and good deals on pitchers of beer.....Back in the day I remember that Cybelle's was right next door (Monster Slice for the crab walk home)   The Valley Tavern is ok but I miss the old days of the R&R
author: Mike S.

description: Cool enough place. Lots of people, but still didn't wait long for a drink. Awesome neighborhood place for after work de-compression.
author: Art W.

description: Went to Valley Tavern for Pub Quiz night last night.  Had a good time.  Beer was a little pricey.  Quiz was really hard.  Nice facility.  Friendly enough people.  Not special, but a fun place to do Quiz Night.
author: Eric S.

description:
this place would get 5 stars if...

1. the giants game was automatically on. we had to ask to change the channel.
2. they didnt have wwe or wwf whatever its called wresting on.
3. THEY HAD BEER PONG tables set up.

now i didnt really go to the back. i just saw some pool tables. but they were full. but seriously this would be my bar if they had beer pong.

not too crowded. seating. sports. variety of beer on tab. jager. jager. JAGER!!! chilled jager i might add.

oh and they have these beer dispensers for like $24 that has like 4 pitchers of beer in it. oh so awesome! so awesome!

anyways. good time.
author: A. V.

description:
A very nice place to hang out with your friends on a fine Monday afternoon which there is a cozy back patio where it is quite private from the bustling summer group which Noe Valley brings. With the beer selection I found that it was quite premium all together with at least, as I can recall, 15 beers on draft / tap, which in my opinion with the selections were all great ones. They had Sierra Nevada, Blue Moon (my choice), Guinness, and for the recession people, PBR. 
It's sad that the patio closes at 7:30, so if you go there late, you should of gone during the day. The bartenders are very nice and will let you watch your choice of sports game without any hassle or "can't do it, boss doesn't like hockey". 
If you're in the Noe Valley area or off of 24th during the day and want a drink, come check this place out. The bar altogether brings a nice atmosphere and positive environment (which is weird to say for a bar), but you'll enjoy the conversations which come with the place.
author: Jon-o G.

description: Great music, but  not a great stand-out besides that.  Average three stars here...although I went on a Wednesday night, so I assume things improve on days when there are actually other people in the bar.
author: Eric M.

description: Much like the Dubliner, a great local bar that has enough going for it to be a destination for people who live in other parts of the city.  Plenty of good beers on tap.  It has a spacious main room with several tables and a decent-sized bar. There's a pool table in back, and for you smokers, there's an open air smoking room that faces the street.
author: Andrew E.

description: I enjoy the fact that this bar has pool tables!!! And you can always get an opportunity to play. Every now and then you might have to put up with a silly drunk, but for the most part, it is not bad! I have not tried the food at the tavern, it does look appetizing though!!
author: sonam d.

description: Cool local bar.  Always showing multiple games.  Cool outdoor patio too.  The best part for me is there are nover any pacmina's in the bar.  :)
author: Fred R.

description: A typical neighborhood bar in a neighborhood where such bars are atypical.  This and the Dubliner down the street are the only ones (Bliss is trying to be more upscale and trendy).  I definitely appreciated the mini pool tables and the variety of miniature-sized pool cues.  Very useful when you pack them into a space this tight.  The outdoor patio in back was closed behind locked door, but of course, I went back there anyhow to scope out the setting.  Looks like it would be nice on a fine summer day.  Will have to come back if we ever see the light of summer again....
author: Rick H.

description: I dig this bar for a variety of reasons, but summin' it up- It just says"friendly".  Always a good vibe in here, especially on Mondays with the quiz-type game.  It's in my 'hood, but we'll always walk past 2 or 3 bars just to go to this one.  'Nuff said?
author: Afab M.

description: Ahhh, I love this place.  Good times, good people, great bloody marys, what else can you ask for?
author: kerry l.

description: Very neighborhood-esque. We went with two regulars who knew the waitress by name so the service was great. About 15 beers on tap, some more unique than others. Full bar, and they'll make you whatever you like. Including a "bloody amaretto" from what I understand. Mostly a middle aged crowd so not the most "happenin" place. Not a good place to "go out," but a great place to meet up with friends over a drink.
author: Halley B.

description: Definitely agree with Mike's review:  this place is a cool hangout with decently strong drinks and a relaxed setting.  They may not serve some of the trendier drinks like mojitos, but they whip up a pretty good dirty Grey Goose martini for a relatively low price.
author: Helen C.

description: People in Dublin have no idea what an Irish car bomb is. They would find it offensive that you're mixing their Guinness with other crap. But the Valley Tavern serves GREAT Irish car bombs. Drinking is fun.
author: Lisa H.

description: My favorite locals bar in SF.  Def biased because I live in Noe
author: Sam G.

description: Ah... lovely Chimay White on tap! Get yourself a glass and sit in their little smoking alcove overlooking 24th street. During the daytime, it's a sunny little perch from which you can watch the world go by.
author: Maureen G.

description: This is a great spot to get a quiet drink with friends.  Even on the weekends, you can pretty much always find a seat.  There are two pool tables, although there really should only be one in the space they have.  They have an outside patio with heat lamps open until 8pm and they have a smoking vestibule in the front open all night.  They have an internet jukebox and wifi.  All the bartenders are awesome and the drinks are reasonable.  It's one of those rare places where you can be comfortable showing up in evening wear or in sweat pants.
author: angela k.

description: I love this place! I try to stop by on the weekends since I don't live in the neighborhood. Good atmosphere, friendly bartenders, great selection of beer. What more can one ask for in a neighborhood pub?
author: Larry J.

description: Great local!  If you're on upper 24th, it's the place to drink.  Friendlier than the Dubliner, and especially the "Noe" on Church.  Only problem: no real food . . . but you don't go there to eat.  There's a smoking room as well if you haven't quit.  I step in for second hand smoke, just to remember the old days.
author: Michael M.

description: Under rated joint in an under rated hood...I lived in Noe Valley for almost 3 years and then this place popped up after I left. How typical. In any event, it's very solid...nice dark tavren with good beer and a good juke box. Nice little back patio area as well. Worth a look if you're in Noe Valley and want something less showy than Bliss.
author: Mike P.

description: This is a place that really embraces the mediocre.  Valley Tavern is large and never too crowded, so you can always get a table to sit at, making this a good place to go if you have a small group and just want to sit around and talk. If you like pool, the tables in the back are good for that.  Other than that, it is a little too big, or echo-y or something.   It's not very cozy or comfortable, the couches are soft and all but they are just too clean!  This place badly needs to be broken in.   Finally, and worst of all, the beer here is too expensive, and there is no happy hour.  The best way to break in a bar, expand your geographic draw, and begin the nurturing of reputation and character that is so essential for a bar is to have a great happy hour....or at least some cheap beer.  A pint of miller light was 4 bucks, thats just silly for a "local" joint.
author: Mr. G.

description: I had a blind date here.  Yeah that's right, this is where people had us meet!  You know what though, it turned out pretty good.  We had a few drinks in this relaxing environment and then once we knew we would not be killed by the other one, we moved on.  It is a great local Noe Valley bar.
author: Pele N.

description: Local neighborhood bar. THe place is cool with good beer. Pools tables are fun but not much room. I love the back porch area. Everyone is pretty chill and there is almost always a seat.
author: Carli M.

description: I just recently found this bar, its in a good location, away from all the mission bars so its a good break from the norm. I walked in to play some pool. I am easily impressed but they do have a Internet jukebox which lets you select the songs you may not find at other bars. Pool tables are small but never crowded... I am a fan of the backyard "beer garden" and the front room smoking area. Only complaint would have to be the prices, didn't matter if i was getting a draft or a bottle everything seemed to be 4+ bucks (mission bars around 2.50) but yeah its a good escape, probably catch me there once a week...
author: jamie z.

description: I always have a good time at the Valley Tavern.  Friendly bartenders will loan you dice and play 1-4-24 with you, which is nice.  I went on Sunday with a buddy and we enjoyed the good FREE bbq (how often is free bar food actually tasty? Almost never, I know!) and some cold beers.  Good selection of beer on tap, not totally unfriendly prices (it is Noe Valley after all) and friendly service.  I went back last night for the pub quiz and had a great time, despite a disappointing 3rd place finish.  I blame my teammates and myself for vetoing a couple answers that ended up being right, my bad.
author: Jake S.

description:
I've been here a few times with friends on various nights of the week, most times just to catch up and drink but also once for the quiz.  The place seems friendly enough, parking as you might expect for the area is dreadful but if you're lucky enough check out the car park on the opposite side of the road!  
A good selection of drinks, the music is kept at a reasonable volume and the pool tables are a nice addition which have always been available at some point during the night.  The quiz was fun but at times we struggled to hear some of the questions.  It's worth keeping in mind that this place isn't of any considerable size and is pretty dark, so anyone looking for a quiet drink sitting down might want to either arrive early or look elsewhere.

Overall this place is worth a visit and on the right night can be a lot of fun.
author: P H.

description: The drinks are mixed well.  Great mix of beers on tap.  The male bartender is an interesting character.  All bartenders are friendly.  Place is usually quiet, and I like to sit at the bar, so it works out well.
author: Brett B.

description: So this is really the neighborhood bar!! I live at 24th and Castro and I love this place. Great to watch sports, take friends. They have a great stepped patio out back past the pool tables. Sometimes serve free food for Friday happy hour. This is the place to go if you want the neighborhood bar feeling.
author: julie q.

description: Cool bartenders, 2 pool tables with only sort of enough room to play,  pretty good selection of drinks and plenty of seating.  It's a great bar to end an evening or just relax with people.  It is very rarely crowded.
author: Heidi P.

description: This bar was my local for years when I lived in Noe Valley. It's a great place to play pool because really good players show up all the time. When the regulars call it home, it can make a stranger feel at home. Having been a regular there, I have to say I am still friends with people I met there, even being out of the hood.There are long term bartenders that make the place feel cozy and familiar, and both the smoking room and the back garden are great places to strike up a conversation with someone new. I miss it and wish there was something even a little bit like it in the upper Haight.
author: marci m.

description: nice neighborhood bar. its a good place to go with a group of friends. its usually pretty chill. prices are pretty good from what i remember. the waitresses are pretty attentive and come around pretty often to check on your table.
author: Linda N.

description: If you want to be treated disrespectful come here.   I personally don't like getting ignored when trying to buy a drink just cause the bartendar feels like being a jerk.  Bliss bar a couple of doors down is way nicer and has better service.
author: Patty G.

description: For a local pub, this is my favorite.  There are comfortable leather couches and lots of good beers on draft.  There is even a little smoking lounge in the front and a bigger one in back.  You can get hammered here and they still treat you with respect. This place is as unpretentious as it gets in SF.
author: Bethany L.

description: The Sunday football bbq buffet is awesome!  And yes the beer is cold too.
author: Robert M.

description: jon.......sarah     awesome bartenders   great drinks good crowd        internet jukebox     you can find any songs awesome
author: tommy b.

description: this joint is great -- nice TVs for the sports watching; comfy benches; good beers; cool crowd; pool table in th back; smoking deck; and did i mention this is a dual review?  they deliver mi lindo yucitan!  so much better than your average pub grub.  4 stars for them too!  it all works.
author: e w.

description: great bar with a casual pub-like (yet not scummy) feeling.  the beer selection is really good and i love the fact that you can order the mayan food next door right from your bar booth!
author: Jennifer D.

description:
good ol down to earth bar. it's like cheers..although i'm not sure they know MY name, they def. recognize me and my coworkers when we stroll in here for a long hard day of work.

happy hr special everyday from 5-7, and trivia nights on mondays!

this place is so chill, they let you have your pizza delivered here...which is perfect when you're buzzed and not wanting to go outside for a snack!
author: joanna u.

description: i cant say I minded this place, but its not my scene. first of all, i dont know, i dont like bars that are lit up too much. it scares me, i felt like i was in a rec room at a youth center with the bright lights, and all the video games and pool going on. at least it had a lot of space though, the music was good, and i dont remember the drinks being super expensive
author: Lauren V.

description: being from the UK i really miss pubs and no bars are not pubs. The valley tavern is a great mix of pub and bar. Great atmosphere and really great beer!!
author: Stuart g.

description: i love the valley tavern.  it's a perfect place to have a beer and people watch if your boyfriend insists in watching that thing they call football.  they even have bbq on sundays, and a super fun game called "bags" - it's like a girls version of golden tee.  to top it off - on nice days people seem to forget about their back patio and you often have it to yourself. the bartenders are nice and never seem to cut you off no matter how many jager shots you have, which isn't always a good thing...especially on one of those "lets just have one beer" sundays.
author: B H.

description: i went here for the very first time with my cousin and friends a couple of weekes ago!!  know its not liek the bliss all fancy and stuff.. this is a real neighborhood bar like the peaks just looks better.. but same people... just i had a great time for getting wasted on a week night! had fun taking shots of patron and playing some pool on the 2 tables they have in the back... the bartender sarah was so sweet cant wait to go back for another " just off work getaway"
author: Shauna P.

description: what a chill place!  Great beer and a comfortable layout- booths and barstools as well as 2 pool tables.
author: pauline e.

description: As sportsbars go The Valley Tavern, and consequently The Dubliner (same owner, same block), try very hard but fail as places to go see the "big game". The televisions, while plentiful, have the distinction of being roughly ten feet directly above your head, making for a very sore neck after three hours of football. In addition, the view from the seating area another twenty feet away is no better, and from there you will also have to wait a century before the waitress will arrive to take your order. For that matter I found the bartenders to be completely obnoxious when I sat at the bar. When the waitress came to take my order (at 11 am) I let her know I would need some water to rehydrate first and would then have a beer. She brought me my water. Immediately following, the second waitress behind the bar also asked me what I would like to drink. I told her the same thing. Within fifteen seconds of that conversation the owner approached me from behind the bar as well. He informed me that there was a two drink minimum and that he was "trying to run a business". This all took place within three minutes of my arrival. Is this really the way to treat your customers? Suprisingly, the owner decided to utilize this same setup for both of his pubs.
author: Doug G.
